div.head:
Embleme 31. Of the Secrets of Nature.
The King swimming in the Sea cryescries out with a loud voyce, hee that
will deliver mee shall have great reward.

lg.l: The King oppressed with a weighty Crowne,
FlotingFloating i'thin the Sea, and being like to drownedrown,
CryesCries out for helpehelp, O helpehelp without delay,
And I wish thanks your service will repay:
Be wise, and to my kingdoms mee restore,
That I may favour shew to rich and poorepoor.

div.head: Discourse 31.
div.ab:
The first rudiments of all discipline were anciently the knowledge of -
swimming, and instruction in learning hereupon because the proverb of an
ignorant and unpolishdunpolished men; that hee could neither swimmeswim nor read:
For the Ancients considerdconsidered swimming as a means often times to save and-
deliver the body from the dangers of water, and the knowledge of learning
the mind from the warreswars of fortune: Moreover swimming is very ser
viceable in time of warre, the knowledge of learning in time of peace at-
home: And as wee observe that brutes have their weapons in readinessereadiness, pro
vided by nature, man hands and witt administred instead thereof against-
externall violence, witt to contrive and invent weapons, hands to make and
use them, soe is the faculty of swimming naturally invested in the same
beasts, but not in man: they even young doe often escape out of waters by-
swimming, in which a man though old or never soe strong is suffocated;-
NeedfullNeedful therefore it was to enjoyne the exercise of swimming to children, be
ing often times most conducible to præserve a mans life, that that which was
wanting by nature, might be supplyed by the use of art: The same exercise
have Noble-men, Princes, and Kings used for the safeguard of their body, for-
those descended from noble blood are not wholy exempt from the chances of
fortune, but exposed to them as well as other men: If Dionysius had knowne nei
ther swimming nor learning, when hee was driven out of the kingdome of Si
cily as a tyrant, hee had perished by the waves of the Sea being shipwrecks in
the Corinthian gulphgulf, but escaping the dangers by swimming, hee went to-
Corinthus, where hee sett up a schoole to teach boyes, and professdprofessed humane-
learning, of a King being made a SchoolemasterSchoolmaster, and holding a rod in stead
of a Scepter, from whene that jeering Proverb, Dionysius of CorynthCorinth: In-
like manner if the royallroyal Sonne of the Philosophers had not been able
to swimme, noe man would have heard his voyce, nor releivdrelieved him, being-
long since drowned in the waters: swimming therefore is necessary and-
coḿodiouscommodious to all degrees of men: for though it cannot deliver a man presently
from the surges of the vast ocean, yet it gives time of life, whereby hee
may be saved by others: But the sayd King sustaines himselfe a long-
time, and cryescries out hitherto, though hee be heard or seen by very few by-
reason of the largenesselargeness of the Sea, and remotenesseremoteness of it: for by chance hee
hath touchdtouched upon a rockerock or great stone in swimming, by which to be præ
served, if the waves prævayle. But the quæstion is what is the Sea? I an
swer, the ErythræanErythaean or red sea, subject to the TropickeTropic of Cancer, in-
which, there being great store of MagnettsMagnets in the bottome, it is not safe for
ShippsShips compacted or laden with iron to saylesail: for they might easily be-
drawne to the bottome by the virtue of the MagnettMagnet: which the sayd King
being ignorant of, and the rest perishing the Ship being sunkesunk, hee alone
escaped by swimming. His Crowne shining with orient RubyesRubies continued
with him, by which hee might easily be knowne, and restored to his-
